author: {'steamid': '76561197960940977', 'num_games_owned': 817, 'num_reviews': 381, 'playtime_forever': 321, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 321, 'last_played': 1682537197}
review:
Expensive with no appeal.

The intro video is terrible, and the text went so quickly I barely caught any of the words. Controls include WASD [i]and[/i] the arrow keys, but spacebar is the jump button, which awkwardly leads to you falling to your death if you ever press W or the up arrow out of muscle memory when trying to jump. There's too many controls. Why are there slopes [i]and[/i] shooting if you can't aim the gun? Your shots just go into the ground. Recharging energy turns out to be a gimmick that pointlessly added another button. A sprinting attack button was added, but you can barely see the level around you, so sprinting often just sends you to your death. The most unnecessary button is one that damages enemies if you land on them (for example after jumping) - why would it be fun to have to press that button? It's like firing a bullet, but the bullet only inflicts damage if you arbitrarily had to press an extra button after firing the gun.

All the attacks are pointless when you can't harm the shield zombies, which only seem to be killed when a yellow star hits them from above (or weirdly when you stand so close to them that you can shoot them because your gun pokes through their shield). The jumps are too frustrating, as you need to do them perfectly, but the character slides on the slightest of gradients, and I died many times because I hit W or the up arrow out of muscle memory or because the jumps (and sprints) don't even work a lot of the time. You get shot from off-screen. Pointless turrets just kill the enemies for you half the time. It's not clear what you can stand on and what will cause you to fall through the map. Your view is often obscured by objects like trees for some reason. There's stars you're supposed to pick up, but your character will slide past them and can't move back up the level, so you'd have to restart the entire level. Why prevent the gameplay from flowing? It makes no sense to force the player to go backwards - especially going back so far.

I have no idea why, but despite reaching the flag at the end of the level, you need to have killed all the enemies for it to end. Why does the game tell you that it's better to run away, and show artwork of running away from zombies if you're supposed to kill them all? They could have left the focus on collecting all the stars. Not only is it a chore to have to kill 100% of enemies, but if you knock one off the map it doesn't seem to die. Going back through the map to fruitlessly hunt for the last enemy is a nightmare because you can barely see anything when it's designed as a one-way system. You also end up going backwards because the level design confusingly forks both ways. Some of the achievements are broken, and the audio is poor - one of the tracks is the same as the menu music in [i]20 Minutes Till Dawn[/i]. There was clearly no optimization when this short platformer is over twice the disc size of Half-Life. The game doesn't have the quality, and isn't fun enough to be worth ¬£1, let alone ¬£10. Where's the originality? It's a butchered (and glitchy) copy of an original Mario game, except you play as Bart Simpson.

review:
[b]My playtime:[/b] I played this game offline but I finished it in around 6h.
[b]Grindy Achievement:[/b] No.
[b]Optional Achievement:[/b] Yes (22 achievements).
[b]Difficult Achievement:[/b] No.
[b]Developer Response:[/b] No (last response is in 4 Jan, 2017).

[h1]Intro[/h1]
[i]Charlie's Adventure[/i] is a platformer game where you have to kill zombies and avoid obstacles to reach your goal. The game has 12 levels in total with 3 different difficulty settings.

Pros:
- 12 levels
- 3 different difficulties
- 3 different attack types
- Combo system to finish the zombie
- A lot of different zombies

Cons:
- Bugs
- Sometimes the camera shoots off-screen
- FPS drop if you respawned a lot of times

[h1]Should you buy this game?[/h1]
[b]Yes.[/b]
[i]If you like to play platformer games, buy this game. It's a steal when it's on discount.[/i]

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
[h1]In-Depth Review[/h1]

[h1]Graphics[/h1]
The game looks cute with its 2D graphics and most of the objects are recognizable. The zombies also look different from each other and you'll be able to notice them right away. The backgrounds are beautiful with their vibrant color and fantasy-like setting. The only thing that bugs me is the fact that sometimes the objects (either you, traps, or zombies) are hidden behind the bushes, making it hard to see.

[h1]Story[/h1]
The game tells its story through a series of pictures that happen before or after you finish a level. To be honest, I couldn't make out most of the story because the cutscene tends to be glitchy and skip a lot, but the game doesn't have much in the story anyway so you can guess or ignore the whole thing.

[h1]The game[/h1]
There are 3 difficulty settings in this game: easy, medium, and hard. I played the hard difficulty because I wanted to get all the achievements and I didn't have any trouble with the difficulty.

You'll have three different attacks in this game. You can shoot a Kamehameha-like thing with A button (you can also hold it to charge the ball to be bigger), dash and damage the enemy with S button, and slam the ground (after you jump beforehand) with D button. You'll get invisibility when you're attempting the second and third attacks and you can spam the attacks repeatedly until your energy runs out. Each attack uses different amounts of energy and you can charge them by pressing up arrow.

There are also a lot of different enemies in this game; there are zombies that can shoot projectiles, ram to your direction when they see you, immune to projectiles, and many others. Each zombie can and should be treated differently and sometimes, chaining your attacks becomes vital to defeating them. You'll have to master your dash and slam to chain combos and defeat most of the enemies while your trusty Kamehameha can help you to deal with the leftovers. Killing the zombies will recover some of your HP and energy bar after a certain amount of time has passed.

Although some zombies might be difficult to beat, I had more trouble dealing with the obstacles in the game. There are a lot of obstacles but the thing that I had the most trouble with is the machines that can shoot arrows or bullets. There were a lot of times where I had no choice but to take some damage from them and ended up having to beat the zombies with low HP. Luckily, zombies can also be killed with these obstacles so they can also help you if you play them right. However, the game has issues with one of its obstacles [spoiler](ax)[/spoiler]. You'll tend to see the object not placed in the correct position and sometimes, it will suddenly reposition itself to its intended position after you move closer to it.

You can collect stars that are scattered at each level. Collecting enough of them will turn you into "Enraged" mode (which is a knock-off version of Super Saiyan) that will increase your speed, jump, and damage. This mode will last for several minutes before it wears off.

All levels are divided through several checkpoints where you can restore your health and respawn on the spot if you die, resetting all of the progress you made up to the point where you reach that checkpoint. Killing zombies are a must in this game because you can only proceed after you clear all of the zombies in the area. Since you can't pass through the checkpoint before killing all the zombies, you can also shove the zombies past the checkpoints to kill them instantly. However, if you collect a star that is located before a checkpoint right after you activate the checkpoint and die, the star will be gone and not counted towards your collection. Luckily, collecting every star isn't a must in this game to finish the game 100% (unless you consider collecting them all as 100% completion, that is).

You'll also be rewarded with stars (a different type from the in-game stars that you collect) after you complete a level. I'm not sure how the game calculates these stars but I managed to get 3 stars (the maximum of what you can get in each level) at all levels from my first try. I did try to collect all in-game stars whenever possible although I'm not sure if that's what the game uses as a basis.

The camera sucks. It only happens in earlier stages, but sometimes, the camera will glitch out, causing the camera to show things away from the center of the screen before it returns to its original position after several minutes. This always happened to me in level 2 where I need to jump across lava and kill a zombie on the other side of the platform; the camera will shoot way below the character until you can't even see him. There's no way I can guess the timing to jump and kill the zombie after I landed without being lucky. I even thought that this level is impossible to beat before I decided to restart the whole level from the beginning. The camera fixed itself that way and the camera issue never happens anymore.

I also noticed FPS drops at certain times in the game, especially after I respawned a lot of times. Note that it still happens after I tweaked the settings to use the lowest graphics quality available. It's not dropping to the point where it's unplayable though, but I think it's worth mentioning.

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
It's an enjoyable platformer game if you don't mind the minor bugs and FPS drop that rarely happens.

Charlie's Adventure is a simple platformer in which we play the role of Charlie who, by opening the box, released a horde of zombies into the world and his goal is to eliminate them.

As Charlie, we can jump, shoot a gun, move faster, and jump on zombies, dealing more damage to them. We have 12 levels at our disposal, unfortunately they are very similar to each other. The game offers a checkpoint system, so if we die we will be moved to the previous checkpoint. To unlock checkpoint we have to kill all zombies on the map.

On each level we can collect stars that affect the result of each level. Apart from that, they have no function, so you don't have to collect them.

Graphically, the game looks like this. At first glance it seems to be nice and pleasant, but if we take a better look it is not so good. It is not ugly graphics, but it is certainly not pretty.

[h1]Sound[/h1]

Soundtrack is average. The music is not very annoying even though it is still the same.

[h1]Summary[/h1]

Charlie's Adventure is almost an average game. Almost, because it's missing something. After I finish this game, I don't feel like playing it again. Despite the relatively low price, I think it should be cheaper.

author: {'steamid': '76561198031654661', 'num_games_owned': 3513, 'num_reviews': 74, 'playtime_forever': 99, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 97, 'last_played': 1540813648}
review:
A huge maybe on this one, it's a pretty short and mediocre platformer with a somewhat interesting moveset. You play as Charlie, who is a pretty ugly protagonist to destroy all of the zombies in the map. The story is pretty dumb and unoriginal and it just kinda ends, so...

Charlie can dash, shoot and do a stomp in order to damage his foes. I do like that two of the moves can also be used for movement, and you can kind of combo into different moves which is fun! It's ruined a bit by a stamina meter though, I really wish it wasn't there and maybe there was just an ammo counter instead. In each area you have to defeat every zombie before moving onto the next checkpoint. It's not a bad concept but it does get repetitive pretty quickly, there is a decent variety in enemy types at the very least - some will jump over or reflect your bullets and some just have a bunch of health.

The presentation is pretty mediocre, the background music in particular is really forgettable. I suppose the in game graphics are alright, sometimes it's a bit confusing on what's a platform or not but it's alright outside of the main character's design in my opinion. I would say try the game out if you got it in a bundle ages ago like I did, or maybe if it's on sale, but the game isn't really anything special and is pretty short...in fact there's this mechanic where you collect stars to briefly become stronger but I forgot about it until just now...

edit: Just looked at the normal price and ¬£4.99? Definitely not worth that!

author: {'steamid': '76561198117837119', 'num_games_owned': 3902, 'num_reviews': 178, 'playtime_forever': 399, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 399, 'last_played': 1517635267}
review:
Charlie's Adventure is about a boy named Charlie who finds a box in his sandbox and opens it. When he opens it he releases zombies into the world. He also obtains some special powers too.

The gameplay is fairly solid. You have a gun to shoot the zombies, a dash move, and a stomp move. The enemies each have their own abilities and ways to counter your abilities. The difficulty differences make the attacks stronger against you and the enemies get more health as difficulty is raised. There's these stars that give you 1.5X increased power for a little while when you collect 10 of them, but the power is pretty short-lived and you end up wasting it because you are just trying to collect them to get the 3 star rank at the end of the level.

The story is very bland. Other than the introduction and the ending, inbetween some levels there's a brief cinematic that doesn't tell you much. The visuals are okay. They're very childish, as you do play a boy named Charlie, but he happens to look like a preteen with a mullet. The soundtrack and sound effects aren't very exciting either.

Overall, this isn't a terrible game, but it's farther from good than bad. There's plenty of 2D platformer shooters out there, but this one probably wouldn't stand out as being great for anyone. Save your money for a better 2D platformer shooter, this one probably isn't worth your money.

review:
Hey everyone and this is my review about the game!

This is a Platformer game.


[h1]Interface/Menu/Settings[/h1]

There are some resolution sizes available.
You can play windowed mode or fullscreen mode.
There is a music volume slidebar available.
There is a sound volume slidebar available.
You can play the game with a xbox controller.
You are able to change the controls on the keyboard and controller.
There is a difficulty level settings available.

[h1]About the game.[/h1]

You are playing with a boy that once digging into a sandbox. At oint point he found a box and from that moment a new adventure begins. You are able to dash through zombies to do some damage, during dashes you won't take any damage. You are able to shoot zombies with a gun, Charging your gun will do alot more damage but it will also consume enegy. Energy will be consumed by dashes/gun/stomps. You are able to stomp enemies while in mid air. Energy will slowly refill back unless you kill an enemy, they will drop an "energy cell" which will fill your energy bar a bit more. You can't go beyond a checkpoint if zombies are still alive. You will have to kill all zombies before you are able to continue your adventure. You can press a button to reveal the locations of zombies. Getting enough stars will make you into "enrage", you damage is slightly increased for a short period of time. If you have died for whichever reason, you will be teleported back to your last checkpoint. All progress that you have done will be reset and you will have to redo them over again.



You have a health bar and there is a damage counter.
There are 12 levels.
Collecting stars will let you go into enrage mode which will temporary give you more damage.
There is an ingame tutorial available.
There are checkpoints available.
All zombies needs to be killed before you are able to get your checkpoint.
Once died, All progress will be reset to your last checkpoint.
Graphics reminds me of a flash game.
Music is okay.
Gameplay is okay.
Unlimited lives, but you have a health bar.
There are achievements.
There is a star rating available. 3 stars can be collected in each level

[h1]Other things.[/h1]

Once your energy is low, you can't attack or hurt enemies. You will have to wait until you have regain some energy or they will die at a trap. If an enemy is dead they will drop a green energy cell which will restore your health and energy for abit. You will have to make sure you aren't on a bad location once your energy is running out as you can no longer dash/stomp or shoot. Energy balls will automatically fly towards your direction.

-------------------

I Give this game a 7/10

review:
Casual platformer.

Full disclaimer: I'm not really a platformer person. I tend more towards FPSs (DOOM) and ARPGs (Dark Souls) so maybe not the best person to review.

That said, I thoroughly enjoyed this. 

Gameplay is fairly well balanced, with a good range of weapons, and difficulty. Fun achievements; nothing impossible. Decent stage variety (e.g, stages with only a few enemies but harder terrain/traps, lots of enemies spread out, lots of platforms (teeter totters, moving islands) where the point is to go find the enemies). Checkpoint distance varies, but is never too far apart (ok, maybe [spoiler]3rd stage of level 10, which was an utter gangbang, but apart from that...[/spoiler]). 

There are no really impossible-to-make timing moves or jumps, and the level design is never unfair/mean-spirited, meaning that if you miss a jump (even on the teeter-totters) you generally wind up not dying (apart from some obvious traps). Though some of the star placements are a bit sadistic.

The animations cracked me up, and are the reason I bought it (coupon from badge crafting, but honestly it's worth the full 4 bucks). And ok, there are some spelling errors in the UI, but somehow that just adds to the silliness. You do this insane cackle every time you get health too, which just never gets old. Soundtrack fits in well.

Couple of weird glitches: flying axes(?); floating platform on level 10 seems to hover for about 10 seconds before moving; you very occasionally get stuck somewhere and have to reload the level. 

Two warnings: 1) If you start a game on one difficulty and then start a new game on another difficulty, you lose the current game, so complete that playthrough first. 2) If you are in the middle of a level and you exit, you have to replay the whole level, there are no save slots. The levels aren't that long though.

Recommended.

review:
When you start the game its default state is the highest resolution and there is no way to change this once you enter a level. This caused my cutscenes to glitch out super hard and lag the entire first two levels before i realized the problem. If you want to play this game, change the settings to something appropriate to your system. SETTINGS ARE NOT SAVED BETWEEN PLAY SESSIONS.

I'm just going to list off all my problems i ran into with the game. Its not the worse game i've ever played, theres a good bit of variety and content in here, but these issues kept me from sticking with the game.

The game is a pretty linear platformer that has no real branching paths. It gives you attacks like dashes, a ground pound, and a gun. The gun is so much stronger than the rest of your weapons theres no reason to use anything else, especially because the movement feels weird and makes landing dashes and groundpounds akward. The camera moves around wildly, partially i think because of the jump height. They made your character rather small on screen, and to help the player move around that screen your player has a massive jump height. This makes some sequences a bit hard to track and i ended up pausing the game a bunch to try and get a better sense of where i was going. The jumping itself moves a bit more than i would like and the speed combined with the rough camera means that it's hard to judge exactly where you will land. Also a minor annoyance was that i ran into a glitch where a zombie was standing on a fire that was supposed to kill it, and you can't progress in the game until every zombie is killed. The art in the backgrounds is similar to art in the foreground and sometimes, especially with tree branches, it's hard to tell which part you're supposed to jump on.

That's all my complaint. Honestly the game is alright, and these devs have made a lot of stuff that i like so i'll try to stick with it a little longer, but personally i wouldn't recommend this game to anyone given the plethora of good platformers/brawlers on steam.

review:
When I open the game it is called SpaceeZombies and not Charlie's Adventure. The game probably changed name during production but someone who had to change this detail didn't do his job... I guess this explains a lot of thing about this game.

First thing first, if you are a game developer and feel the need to create some platformer style game like this one, make sure  to center properly the action on the character that the player is going to play with and refrain from making some "half-baked" setup that makes the screen jerk right, left, up and down every time you jump a little bit too far making the game practically impossible to enjoy... It's annoying.

Second thing, do not overload the screen with visual content that hide the character when you go forward or other foreground elements that we can live without... It is not needed.

Third thing, do not add cannons and turrets just for the sake of adding some weird difficulty layer to your game if it does not make any shred of sense... It is illogical.

Finally, do not attempt to burn the retina of the players by overusing bloom and light effects... It burns.

I will conclude this review by saying that I understand that this game was a labor of love for whoever made it but I wonder if you had more fun creating or contemplating the end result.

A good platform game with basic controls. As far is I haver gotten I've seen 4 enemies the basher, the thrower, the mad bomber and the healer. There also are different kind of traps layout through each lvl like a cannon ball shooter, a bow and arrow that aim where you are moving to and an axe that swing from left to right. So far, the only real issue I have with this game is the bugs that sometimes happen in those lvl like an axe that move out of it's place, The platform that suddenly go diagonal instead of horizontal. 

The checkpoint system is OK and you frequently get same hitpoints back by defeating zombies. 

All in all I would recommend this game for the fair price it offers since it give you a fair ammount of gameplay. I think this game would give you around 3-7 hours of gameplay which is more than enough to justify it's value.

author: {'steamid': '76561198053788131', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 352, 'playtime_forever': 124, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 124, 'last_played': 1482043421}
review:
[h1]OVERVIEW[/h1]
Charlie's Adventure is a relatively short two-dimensional platformer from indie developers, Just1337 Studios.

In Charlie's Adventure you play the titular Charlie, a young boy who, upon finding a strange box in his sand pit and opening it, unwittingly causes zombies to invade the world. Never fear, though, the same box seems to have given Charlie various strange powers with which he can combat the undead horde.

[h1]Graphics[/h1]
Graphics are mostly fairly bright and colourful. Character sprites are relatively simple, but nicely drawn, with smooth animations. Level backgrounds progress through a few different themes and include animations, some of which tend to distract from the main action. Cut scenes are hand drawn and possess a certain charm, with crude animations that remind me of nothing more than Beavis and Butthead, but maybe that's just me.

[h1]Sound[/h1]
Background music is nice, with a spooky theme that fits the game well. It's not the sort of music you'd by a soundtrack for, but it's good enough. Sound effects are mostly good, but there's an annoying evil laugh sound that I didn't like much, and I'm still not sure if it's supposed to be from Charlie or one of the zombies. The star-collecting sound reminds me of a Mario game.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
Charlie's Adventure plays like a typical 2D platformer. Using keyboard or controller you can move left and right, jump, double-jump, and dash, as you make your way around the various platforms, collecting stars, avoiding traps, and killing zombies. Falling off the bottom of the screen kills you, putting you back to the last-visited checkpoint. 

Charlie has a fairly impressive arsenal for a little boy. Having found a 'phazer' he can shoot zombies with that, or charge it up for mega-damage shots. He can also slam zombies from above when jumping over them, or charge into them as part of his dash, which also makes Charlie briefly invincible to zombie and trap damage. All of these moves use some of his magic energy reserves, though, so keep an eye on the meter in the top left when you're in a fight, as running out at an inopportune time can leave Charlie in a bit of a pickle.

Each level is divided up into a number of areas marked by checkpoints. Kill all of the zombies in one area to unlock the checkpoint to the next, and then reach the checkpoint in order to have Charlie reappear there upon death. Charlie's final ability can help in some of the more convoluted areas, too: find zombies. This ability shows little arrows pointing from Charlie to each of the remaining zombies in Charlie's current area.

Each area has a number of gold stars that Charlie can collect by running into them, as well. Collect enough of these and Charlie becomes 'enraged' for a short time, increasing speed and damage. Watch out, though; even though Charlie's more of a bad-ass when enraged, he still takes the same amount of damage from traps and zombies.

There are 12 levels in Charlie's Adventure. I haven't completed them all, but I've played for about two hours, including some alt-tabbing to take notes for this review, and I've completed over half of them. That suggests the game is relatively short, although you can always go back and play again at one of the other difficulty levels if you're really keen. I expect only die-hard achievement hunters will both with that, though, as the levels are all very similar, both to each other and many other games in the genre, so there's nothing here to really grab your attention and drag you back to play again.

I found the keyboard controls a bit awkward, and they seemed to not be configurable. Controller support was good, but I found it a bit less precise than the keyboard, so neither was quite perfect. In both modes my most frequent cause of death was pressing the shoot button when I meant to press the dash.

I encountered a couple of frustrating problems in Charlie's Adventure. Firstly, on one level it was frustrating to collect a star close to the bottom of the screen because just touching that area of the screen caused Charlie instant death. I had to try that one multiple times before I managed to grab it without touching the 'death zone'. Secondly, on one occasion I managed to knock a zombie backwards behind a part of one level that Charlie was unable to get to, meaning that I had to kill Charlie off and restart that area. Neither of these was too problematic, though, and the game seems very stable; I didn't encounter any other bugs or crashing. I did see a few grammatical errors in the game, though. Oh, and some of the achievements don't seem to quite work right, so any achievement hunters might want to keep an eye out to see if they drop.

[h1]PROS AND CONS[/h1]
Pros:
+ A certain sort of charm to the character sprites and animations, and the cut scenes
+ Solid platforming action
+ Spooky music
+ Steam achievements and trading cards

Cons:
- A bit boring; doesn't do anything out of the ordinary
- A couple of small problems make it more frustrating than it should be
- Short

[h1]CONCLUSION[/h1]
Charlie's Adventure is a solid indie platformer that fans of the genre should enjoy. It doesn't bring anything revelatory to the genre, but it gets the basics right.

[h1]60/100[/h1]
